PER CURIAM: Linda R. Galloway appeals the Administrative Law Court's
  (ALC) order reversing the South Carolina Division of Motor Vehicle Hearings'
  (hearing officer) order rescinding the suspension of Galloway's driver's
  license.Â  We affirm[1] pursuant to Rule 220(b), SCACR, and the following authorities.
1.Â Â Â Â Â Â  As
  to whether the ALC erred by failing to set forth a specific ground for
  overturning the hearing officer's decision: S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 1-23-380 (5)(e)
  (Supp. 2008) (providing an appellate court may reverse or modify the decision
  of the agency if the substantial rights of the appellant have been prejudiced
  because the administrative findings, inferences, conclusions or decisions are
  clearly erroneous in view of the reliable, probative, and substantial evidence
  on the whole record).
2.Â Â Â Â Â Â  As to
  whether the ALC erred in reversing the
  hearing officer's holding that the police officer's testimony was insufficient
  to establish the officer provided Galloway the correct implied consent
  advisement: S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 56-5-2950 (Supp. 2008) (providing the arresting
  officer must provide the implied consent advisement in writing prior to
  administering a breath test, and setting forth the implied consent advisement); Felder v. Johnston, 127 S.C. 215, 217, 121 S.E. 54, 54 (1924) ("In
  the absence of evidence to the contrary, courts are bound to presume that
  public officers have properly discharged their duties and that their acts are
  in all respects regular.").
AFFIRMED. 
HUFF,
  WILLIAMS, and KONDUROS, JJ., concur.


[1] We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to
  Rule 215, SCACR.

  375 S.C. 259, 265, 652 S.E.2d 90, 93 (Ct. App. 2007).Â  "A change in
  condition occurs when the claimant experiences a change in physical condition
  as a result of her original injury, occurring after the first award."Â  Id.Â

  in condition resulting from his original work injury.Â  Substantial evidence in

REVERSED


  
    
      
        Attorney

          Assistant Deputy Attorney General Salley W. Elliott, and Senior Assistant
          Attorney General Norman Mark Rapoport, all of Columbia; and Solicitor Kevin S.

          A. Wellborn, of Rock Hill, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â 
  On September 12, 2006, a Clover police officer entered the Friendly Mart to
  investigate a report of illegal video poker machines at the establishment.Â  He
  noticed video screens in an open storage room simultaneously go dark as he
  entered the store.Â  After viewing the dark machines, he asked That Tran, the
  store owner, to turn them back on.Â  Tran complied without objection, and the
  machines displayed a video game known to the officer to be illegal.Â  The police
  department then seized all three video machines, and Tran was indicted for operating a gaming house and
  possession of gambling devices.Â  Tran made a pretrial motion to suppress
  evidence of the poker machines.Â  The circuit court granted Tranâ€™s motion.Â  The State appealed.Â  
The
  State argues the circuit court erred in suppressing the video poker machines
  because their discovery falls within the plain view exception to the Fourth
  Amendment prohibition against warrantless searches.Â  We agree.
In
  criminal cases, the appellate court sits to review errors of law only.Â  State
    v. Butler, 353 S.C. 383, 388, 577 S.E.2d 498, 500 (Ct. App. 2003).Â 
  Our review in Fourth Amendment search and seizure cases is limited to
  determining whether any evidence supports the circuit courtâ€™s finding.Â  State
    v. Bowman, 366 S.C. 485, 501, 623 S.E.2d 378, 386 (2005).Â  The Fourth
  Amendmentâ€™s exclusionary rule prohibits unreasonable searches and seizures. 
  U.S. Const. amend. IV; see also S.C. Const. art. I, Â§ 10.  Evidence
  seized in violation of the Fourth Amendment is inadmissible.  State v.
    Forrester, 343 S.C. 637, 643, 541 S.E.2d 837, 840 (2001).  â€œGenerally,
  a warrantless search is per se unreasonable and thus violative of the Fourth
  Amendmentâ€™s prohibition against unreasonable searches and seizures.â€  State
    v. Bultron, 318 S.C. 323, 331, 457 S.E.2d 616, 621 (Ct. App. 1995).  However,
  a warrantless search may be constitutional if it falls within a recognized
  exception.Â  Id. at 331-32, 457 S.E.2d at 621.  Under the plain view
  exception, â€œa law enforcement officer who is lawfully in a position to view
  [an] objectâ€ may seize it.Â  State v. Abdullah, 357 S.C. 344, 352, 592
  S.E.2d 344, 349 (Ct. App. 2004).Â  The plain view doctrine applies when â€œâ€˜(1)
  the initial intrusion which afforded the authorities the plain view was lawful;
  (2) the discovery of the evidence was inadvertent; and (3) the incriminating
  [nature of the] evidence was immediately apparent to the seizing
  authorities.â€™â€Â  Id. at 352-53, 592 S.E.2d at 349 (quoting State v.
    Culbreath, 300 S.C. 232, 237, 387 S.E.2d 255, 257 (1990)).Â  The United
  States Supreme Court has eliminated the requirement that the discovery be
  inadvertent, as long as the seizure meets the other two requirements.Â  Horton
    v. California, 496 U.S. 128, 130 (1990).
The
  seizure in this case clearly fell within the plain view exception.Â  The
  officerâ€™s entry into the Friendly Mart, a place of business, and into the open
  storage room was lawful.Â  The officer encountered no signage or barrier
  indicating the storage room was off-limits to customers, and store personnel
  did not attempt to stop him entering the room.Â  The circuit court erred in
  finding the seizure failed the remaining prong of the plain view test, that the
  incriminating nature of the machines be immediately apparent.Â  The evidence did
  not indicate the police conducted an additional search of the video poker
  machines or otherwise forced them to reveal their programming.Â  Rather, Tran
  maintained full control of them until their seizure.Â  At the request of a man
  who had not identified himself as a police officer, Tran consensually turned on
  the machines and displayed their incriminating nature.Â  
Because
  the officer observed the machines while lawfully present in the Friendly Mart
  and seized them only after the storeâ€™s owner willingly displayed their
  programming contents, their seizure falls into the plain view exception to the
  exclusionary rule.Â  Consequently, the circuit court erred in suppressing the
  seized machines.Â  
REVERSED.
HEARN,
  C.J., SHORT and KONDUROS, JJ., concur.

PER CURIAM: Willard M. Williams along with Charles C. Bozeman (Bozeman) and
  Robin C. Bozeman appeal the trial court's grant of summary judgment to Dease
  Construction on their causes of action for negligent entrustment (Issue I). Â Williams
  also argues a genuine issue of material fact exists regarding whether Bozeman
  was negligent because he presented evidence Bozeman was speeding and caused the
  accident (Issue II).Â  We
  affirm pursuant to Rule 220(b)(1), SCACR, and the following authorities: Issue
  I: Fleming v. Rose, 350 S.C. 488, 493, 567 S.E.2d 857, 860 (2002)
  (providing summary judgment is proper when there is no genuine issue as to any
  material fact and the moving party is entitled to judgment as a matter of law); Am. Mut. Fire Ins. Co. v. Passmore, 275 S.C. 618, 621, 274 S.E.2d 416,
  418 (1981) ("The theory of negligent entrustment provides: 'the owner
  or one in control of the vehicle and responsible for its use who is negligent
  in entrusting it to another can be held liable for such negligent entrustment.'
  "); Wineglass v. McMinn, 235 S.C. 537, 541,
  112 S.E.2d 652, 654 (1960) (holding ample evidence established the
  appellants' agent was negligent in leaving an inexperienced, fourteen-year-old
  to attend to the truck with ignition key because the employee "should have
  foreseen as a reasonable and probable consequence . . . the safety of others on
  the street would be endangered by the boy's attempt to drive it"); Dennis by Evans v. Timmons, 313 S.C. 338, 341, 437 S.E.2d 138, 141 (Ct.
  App. 1993) ("When a person has not furnished the instrumentality but through
  negligence allowed access thereto to a child, the standard for imposing
  liability upon the person is whether the person knew of the child's proclivity
  or propensity for the specific dangerous activity which caused the harm.");
  and Issue II: Coleman v. Shaw, 281 S.C. 107, 110, 314
  S.E.2d 154, 156 (Ct. App. 1984) (holding violation of a statute is
  negligence per se but once established, the court must still examine the
  question of proximate cause); Rayfield v. S.C. Depâ€™t of Corr., 297 S.C.
  95, 103-04, 374 S.E.2d 910, 915 (Ct. App. 1988) ("Negligence per se simply means the jury need not decide if the defendant acted as
  would a reasonable man in the circumstances. Â The statute fixes the standard of conduct required of the
  defendant, leaving the jury merely to decide whether the defendant breached the
  statute. Â If he did, his failure to take due care is established as a matter of
  law. The only issue then left for the jury to determine is the third element of
  negligence, . . . whether the defendant's conduct proximately caused damage to
  the plaintiff."); Blanding v. Hammell, 267 S.C. 352, 357, 228
  S.E.2d 271, 272-73 (1976) (holding when "speed has not been a causative
  factor, the court has focused on the inevitability of the accident, irrespective of the defendant's
  speed, due to an unexpected entry of the plaintiff into the defendant's right
  of way"); Odom v. Steigerwald, 260 S.C. 422, 428, 196 S.E.2d 635,
  638 (1973) ("Assuming . . . the plaintiff was driving at an excessive rate
  of speed and was negligent, we think, as a matter of law, that such was not a
  contributing proximate cause. The real cause, the more immediate and efficient
  cause, was the improper driving conduct of [the defendant]. Â By driving his car
  directly into the path of plaintiff's vehicle when plaintiff was obviously so
  close to the intersection, [the defendant] created a trap from which plaintiff
  could not escape.").
AFFIRMED.
HEARN,
  C.J., and SHORT and KONDUROS, JJ., concur.

PER CURIAM:Â  In this case, the State asserts the dismissal of a traffic

1.  The gravamen of the State's argument on appeal is that based
  upon the Francis Marion University (FMU) campus police officer's status as a
  State Constable, the officer possessed statewide authority to issue citations
  at any location in the state.Â  However, other than a bald assertion of
  statewide authority, the campus officer's constable status was never
  established before the magistrate although the officer was given an opportunity
  to do so.Â  We question whether the issue was properly preserved by the
  officer's unsupported assertion before the magistrate; however, even if we were
  to consider the officer's constable commission submitted by the State for the
  first time on appeal, that commission nonetheless is dated after the date of
  the offense herein.Â  Accordingly, the officer's statewide authority was never
  established.

  Carolina Code (2007) due to the officer's alleged status as a State Constable
  at the time he issued the ticket and due to FMU's classification as a public

  However, the campus officer's status as a State Constable is dispositive under

  circuit court's statutory interpretation of Â§ 59-116-10 et. seq. was

Appeal From Richland County
Â G. Thomas Cooper, Jr., Circuit Court
  Judge
Unpublished Opinion No. 2009-UP-089
Heard January 21, 2009 â€“ Filed February
  23, 2009Â Â Â  
REVERSED AND REMANDED


	
		
			
				Charles Edward Johnson, of Columbia, for Appellant.
				Andrew E. Haselden, of Columbia, for Respondent.
			
		
	

PER
  CURIAM:Â  The Appellate Panel of the South Carolina Workers'
    Compensation Commission (Appellate Panel) awarded benefits to Lishawn Moore.Â 
    The circuit court reversed this award, and Moore appeals.Â  We reverse.Â Â Â  
FACTS
Moore
  was employed by the South Carolina Department of Corrections (Department) as a
  corrections officer at Allendale Correctional Institution (ACI).Â  From June 1
  to June 3, 2004, Moore worked twelve-hour shifts, from 6:00 p.m. to 6:00 a.m.Â 
  Because she worked three days and was off two days, Moore was not scheduled to
  work June 4.Â  At the end of her shift on June 3, 2004, Moore left ACI and drove
  to her home in Denmark, thirty minutes away.Â  Upon arriving at home at about
  7:45 a.m., Moore received a telephone call from Officer Holman at ACI, asking
  if Moore had taken home a pair of handcuffs from ACI's Bamberg B-Wing.Â  Moore
  located the handcuffs in her jacket pocket.Â  Although Moore testified she
  believed she needed to return the handcuffs to ACI immediately, Officer Holman
  testified she told Moore she could do so the next time she came into work.[1]Â Â Â  
With
  her young son in the car, Moore drove back to ACI and returned the handcuffs.Â 
  The officer at the front gate, who was expecting Moore, accepted the handcuffs
  and returned them to Bamberg B-Wing.Â  After leaving ACI, Moore stopped at a
  convenience store and purchased a drink for her son.Â  She testified the next
  thing she remembered was waking up with her car off the highway, down an
  embankment, and crashed into a tree.Â  The injuries Moore sustained in the wreck
  left her paraplegic.Â Â  
The
  first single commissioner who reviewed Moore's claim for workers' compensation
  benefits held Moore's injuries were compensable.Â  The Department appealed, and
  the Appellate Panel remanded for a new hearing.Â  The second single commissioner
  also found Moore's injuries compensable, and the Appellate Panel affirmed.Â  The
  Department appealed to the circuit court, which reversed, holding Moore's claim
  was not compensable.Â  Moore appealed to this court.
STANDARD OF REVIEW
In
  reviewing workers' compensation decisions, the appellate court ascertains "whether
  the circuit court properly determined whether the [A]ppellate [P]anel's
  findings of fact are supported by substantial evidence in the record and
  whether the [Appellate P]anel's decision is affected by an error of law."Â  Baxter v. Martin Bros., Inc., 368 S.C. 510, 513, 630 S.E.2d 42,
  43 (2006) (citations omitted); see also S.C. Code Ann. Â§
  1-23-380(5) (Supp. 2008).Â  "'Substantial evidence' is evidence which,
  considering the entire record, would allow reasonable minds to arrive at the
  same conclusion reached by the administrative agency."Â  S.C. Second
    Injury Fund v. Liberty Mut. Ins. Co., 353 S.C. 117, 122, 576 S.E.2d 199,
  202 (Ct. App. 2003).Â  The Administrative Procedures Act does not permit an
  appellate court to "substitute its judgment for that of the [Appellate
  Panel] as to the weight of the evidence on questions of fact."Â  West v.
    Alliance Capital, 368 S.C. 246, 251, 628 S.E.2d 279, 282 (Ct. App. 2006); see also Â§ 1-23-380(5).Â  Â Â 
LAW/ANALYSIS
Moore argues the circuit
  court erred in reversing the Appellate Panel's award of benefits because the
  award was supported by substantial evidence in the record and was not affected
  by an error of law.Â  We
  agree.
In reviewing the Appellate Panel's decision, the circuit court's
  role is limited to determining whether substantial evidence in the record
  supports the Appellate Panel's findings of fact and whether the decision is
  affected by an error of law. Â Baxter
    v. Martin Bros., Inc., 368 S.C. 510, 513, 630 S.E.2d 42, 43 (2006)
  (citations omitted); see also S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 1-23-380(5) (Supp. 2008).
  Â 
In
  reversing the Appellate Panel's decision in favor of its own interpretation of
  the evidence, the circuit court improperly extended the substantial-evidence
  standard of review.Â  Sitting in an appellate capacity, the circuit court was
  tasked with reviewing the Appellate Panel's decision to determine whether
  substantial evidence supported the Appellate Panel's findings.Â  See Baxter, 368
  S.C. at 513, 630 S.E.2d at 43; Â§ 1-23-380(5).Â  Here, the circuit court made its own determinations of
  credibility, holding substantial evidence indicated Moore's trip was not done
  to advance the Department's interest and conferred no actual benefit on the
  Department.Â  At the same time, the circuit court failed to determine whether
  the Appellate Panel's findings were supported by substantial evidence.Â  Rather,
  the circuit court conducted its own evaluation of the merits of the case and
  improperly substituted its judgment for that of the Appellate Panel as to the
  weight of the evidence on questions of fact.Â  See West, 368 S.C. at 251, 628 S.E.2d at 282.Â  This expansion of
  the scope of review was error.Â Â Â  
Inasmuch
  as we have reversed the circuit court's decision because it impermissibly
  expanded the scope of its review, we need not reach whether application of the
  special errand doctrine amounted to an error of law.Â  See Futch v.
    McAllister Towing of Georgetown, Inc., 335 S.C. 598, 613, 518 S.E.2d 591,
  598 (1999) (ruling an appellate court need not review remaining issues when its determination of a
  prior issue is dispositive of the appeal).Â  
CONCLUSION
We
  find the circuit court impermissibly substituted its own judgment for that of
  the Appellate Panel in violation of the substantial evidence scope of review.Â 
  Therefore, the order of the circuit court is 
REVERSED
  AND REMANDED.
SHORT
  and KONDUROS, JJ., and CURETON, A.J., concur.


[1] Although testimony indicated Department policy
  required weapons to be returned immediately, the witnesses were aware of no
  such policy specifically pertaining to handcuffs and no other incidents
  involving handcuffs inadvertently removed from ACI.Â Â Â

PER CURIAM: This
  appeal arises after Henri Ann Logan, a real estate attorney, discovered
  Wachovia made three banking errors concerning her attorney trust account.Â 
  Wachovia made the banking errors in 1999, and Logan filed suit against Wachovia
  on August 13, 2004.Â  The trial court granted Wachovia summary judgment because
  Logan failed to comply with the three-year statute of limitations.Â  Logan
  appeals this ruling and argues the trial court erred by 1) granting Wachovia's
  summary judgment motion because her lawsuit concerns Wachovia's actions after
  she discovered their mistakes; 2) granting Wachovia summary judgment on her
  defamation cause of action; 3) denying her motion for summary judgment; 4)Â 
  failing to find Wachovia should be estopped from asserting certain defenses
  including the statute of limitations defense; 5) finding a purported 1997
  agreement was the contract between the parties; 6) failing to find unjust
  enrichment applied to her case; and 7)Â  prematurely granting summary judgment.Â  We affirm.[1]
1.Â  The trial court did not
  err in granting Wachovia's summary judgment motion based on the statute of
  limitations.Â  In South Carolina a party must commence an action within three
  years of the date the cause of action arises.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 15-3-530
  (2005).Â  The three-year statute of limitations "begins to run when the underlying
  cause of action reasonably ought to have been discovered."Â  Martin v.
    Companion Healthcare Corp., 357 S.C. 570, 575, 593 S.E.2d 624, 627 (Ct.
  App. 2004).Â  Under the discovery rule, "the three-year clock starts
  ticking on the date the injured party either knows or should have known by the
  exercise of reasonable diligence that a cause of action arises from the
  wrongful conduct."Â  Id. at 575-76, 593 S.E.2d at 627 (internal
  citation omitted).Â Â  Further, pursuant to the terms and conditions of Logan's deposit
  account, she agreed to report unauthorized transactions or errors to Wachovia
  within sixty days of receiving her banking statement.Â  As a general rule, in South Carolina, parties may exercise freedom of contract, so long as the contract is
  lawful.Â  Jordan v. Aetna Cas. & Sur. Co., 264 S.C. 294, 297,
  214 S.E.2d 818, 820 (1975) ("While parties are generally permitted to
  contract as they desire, freedom to contract is not absolute and coverage
  required by law may not be omitted."). 
2.Â  The trial court did not
  err in granting Wachovia's summary judgment motion on Logan's defamation
  claim.Â  "In order to prove defamation, a party must show: (1) a false and
  defamatory statement was made; (2) the unprivileged publication of the
  statement to a third party; (3) the publisher was at fault; and (4) either the
  statement was actionable irrespective of harm or the publication of the
  statement caused special harm."Â  Williams v. Lancaster County Sch. Dist., 369 S.C. 293, 302-03, 631 S.E.2d 286, 292 (Ct. App. 2006).Â  Hearsay is a
  "statement, other than one made by the declarant while testifying at the
  trial or hearing, offered in evidence to prove the truth of matter asserted."Â 
  Rule 801(c), SCRE.Â  Generally, hearsay is inadmissible.Â  Rule 802, SCRE.Â  Under
  the South Carolina Rules of Civil Procedure, an affidavit supporting summary
  judgment must be made on personal knowledge, must be admissible, and must show
  the affiant's competency to testify.Â  Rule 56(e), SCRCP ("Supporting and
  opposing affidavits shall be made on personal knowledge, shall set forth such
  facts as would be admissible in evidence, and shall show affirmatively that the
  affiant is competent to testify to the matters stated therein.").Â  
3.Â  The trial court did not
  err in denying Logan's summary judgment motion because this issue is not
  immediately appealable.Â  See Ballenger v. Bowen, 313 S.C. 476,
  476, 443 S.E.2d 379, 380 (1994) (holding "the denial of summary judgment
  is not directly appealable.").Â  Moreover, even in an appeal from a final
  judgment, a denial of summary judgment is not reviewable.Â  Id. at 477,
  443 S.E.2d at 380.Â  Accordingly, we need not address the denial of summary
  judgment issue.
4.Â  The trial court did not
  err in finding Wachovia was not estopped from asserting defenses or in finding
  a 1997 contract was the controlling agreement between the parties.Â  The purpose
  of Rule 59(e), SCRCP, motion is to request for the trial judge to reconsider
  matters properly encompassed in a decision on the merits.Â  Collins Music
    Co., Inc. v. IGT, 353 S.C. 559, 562, 579 S.E.2d 524, 525 (Ct. App. 2002).Â  In Pye v. Estate of Fox, the South Carolina Supreme Court identified two
  ways to preserve an issue for appeal as either: "a ruling by the trial
  [court] or a post-trial motion."Â  369 S.C. 555, 566, 633 S.E.2d 505, 511
  (2006).Â  During the hearing on the summary judgment motion, Logan argued
  Wachovia "should be estopped from even raising the [statute of
  limitations] argument."Â  However, the trial court did not rule on the
  estoppel argument or rule on whether the 1997 contract governed relations
  between the parties at the end of the hearing or in its order granting summary
  judgment. Â Logan should have filed a Rule 59(e) motion, alerting the trial
  court to both issues and giving the court an opportunity these issues.Â  See Pye, 369 S.C. at 565, 633 S.E.2d at 510.Â  Instead, Logan directly
  appealed the trial court's order granting Wachovia's summary judgment motion.Â 
  Because this issue was never raised at the trial level, it is not preserved for
  our review.Â  In re Michael H., 360 S.C. 540, 546, 602 S.E.2d 729, 732
  (2004) ("An issue may not be raised for the first time on appeal.Â  In
  order to preserve an issue for appeal, it must be raised to and ruled upon by
  the trial court.").Â  
5.Â  Logan's unjust enrichment
  argument is abandoned.Â  An issue is deemed abandoned and will not be considered
  on appeal if the argument is raised in a brief but not supported by authority.Â  State v. Jones, 344 S.C. 48, 58-59, 543 S.E.2d 541, 546 (2001).Â  Logan failed to cite any authority in support of her unjust enrichment assertion;
  therefore, she abandoned this issue on appeal.
6.Â  The trial court did not
  prematurely grant Wachovia's motion for summary judgment.Â  Until the opposing
  party has had a full and fair opportunity to investigate, summary judgment is a
  drastic remedy and must not be granted.Â  Dawkins v. Fields, 354 S.C. 58,
  69, 580 S.E.2d 433, 439 (2003).Â  "Nonetheless, the nonmoving party must
  demonstrate the likelihood that further discovery will uncover additional
  relevant evidence and that the party is not merely engaged in a fishing
  expedition."Â  Id. (internal citations omitted). Â Logan did not
  demonstrate further discovery would uncover additional relevant facts.Â 
  Accordingly, the trial court did not prematurely grant summary judgment.Â  
AFFIRMED.
HEARN, C.J., PIEPER and LOCKEMY, JJ., concur.


[1] We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to
  Rule 215, SCACR.

				Claudius Eugene

Submitted November 1, 2008 â€“ Filed
  February 23, 2009
REVERSED


	
		
			
				Kimber Fowler, of Loris, for Appellant.
				Claudus Eugene Fowler, of Loris, for Respondent.
			
		
	

PER CURIAM: Kimber
  Fowler (Appellant) planted Bradford pear trees along an easement Claudus E. Fowler
  (Respondent) claimed across Appellantâ€™s land.Â  When Respondent cut limbs from
  those trees, Appellant filed an action for trespass and property damage.Â  She
  now appeals from the master-in-equityâ€™s order finding Respondent had an
  easement across Appellantâ€™s land.Â  We reverse.[1]
FACTS
I.  Land Conveyances
On
  September 29, 1981, Respondent acquired 3.72 acres of land through a civil suit
  for partition of his fatherâ€™s estate.Â  The estateâ€™s real property was surveyed
  and platted on November 9, 1981.Â  No easement appeared either in Respondentâ€™s
  title or on that plat.Â  
On
  June 17, 1999, Respondentâ€™s land was surveyed and platted in preparation for
  conveyances Respondent intended to make to his children.Â  The plat prepared at
  this time (the Inman Plat) reflects an â€œexisting soil driveâ€ within a
  twenty-five-foot private easement across the north side of the parcel.Â  On
  August 6, 1999, Respondent and his wife conveyed the easternmost 0.99 acres of
  their land to their son and Appellant, their daughter-in-law.Â  Respondent and
  his wife reserved a life estate in the conveyed land.Â  On June 28, 2000, they
  released this right and conveyed their remaining interest in the land to their
  son and Appellant.Â  Although the title references the Inman Plat, neither the
  title nor the release document indicates an easement. Â Â 
Respondentâ€™s
  son and Appellant divorced in January 2005.Â  On April 20, 2005, Appellant
  received title to the 0.99 acres solely in her name pursuant to the divorce
  decree.Â  The title document executed by Respondentâ€™s son references the Inman
  Plat but does not indicate an easement.Â  Â Â 
On
  April 18, 2006, the land was surveyed again at Respondentâ€™s request.Â  The plat
  prepared following this survey reflects a â€œprivate access easementâ€ identified
  as â€œDolly Laneâ€ across the north side of Appellantâ€™s land and references the
  prior plat.Â  Furthermore, this plat appears to indicate a proposed driveway and
  cul-de-sac extending from Dolly Lane across half of Respondentâ€™s property.Â 
  Both the 1981 and 2006 plats show a county road either touching or defining a
  portion of the western boundary of Respondentâ€™s property.[2]Â 
  Â Â 
II.  Background and
  Procedural History
In
  August 2000, Appellant planted eight Bradford pear trees approximately six feet
  from the existing soil drive shown on the Inman Plat.Â  On April 5, 2005,
  Respondent and his grandson destroyed one of those trees.Â  Appellant filed
  criminal charges against them but later withdrew those charges in an effort to
  â€œmake peace with the family.â€Â  On February 8, 2007, Respondent and his grandson
  used a chainsaw to cut branches from the remaining Bradford pear trees, leaving
  marks across the trunks of several of those trees.Â  Subsequently, Appellant
  posted â€œno trespassingâ€ signs on and near the trees.Â  When Respondent removed
  them, Appellant again filed criminal charges against him and a civil suit for
  trespass and malicious damage to her property.Â  
Appellantâ€™s
  civil suit was referred to the master, who ruled in favor of Respondent and
  found Respondent had â€œby dedication a private easement . . . for travel
  purposes of ingress and egressâ€ across Appellantâ€™s land.Â  This appeal
  followed.Â  
LAW/ANALYSIS
I.  Easement by
  Dedication
Appellant
  asserts the master erred in finding Respondent possessed an easement by
  dedication across her land.Â  We agree.
â€œThe determination
  of the existence of an easement is a question of fact in a
  law action and subject to an any evidence standard of review when tried by a
  judge without a jury.â€Â  Hardy v. Aiken, 369 S.C. 160, 165, 631
  S.E.2d 539, 541 (2006).Â  
The master
  erred in concluding Respondent possessed an easement by dedication.Â  South Carolina law presumes a buyer of a lot in subdivided property has a dedicated property
  right in any easements or roads shown on the plat.Â  Inlet Harbour v. S.C.
    Depâ€™t of Parks, Recreation & Tourism, 377 S.C. 86, 92, 659 S.E.2d 151,
  154 (2008); see also Murrells Inlet Corp. v. Ward, 378 S.C. 225,
  233, 662 S.E.2d 452, 455-56 (Ct. App. 2008).Â  While an easement by dedication
  may be described in a plat prepared prior to conveyance of subdivided property,
  no easement legally exists until the seller conveys ownership of a part of that
  property to a buyer.Â  Inlet Harbour, 377 S.C. at 92, 659 S.E.2d at
  154.Â  To create this implied easement, the deed must reference the plat.Â  Id.Â  Once created, the easement benefits the buyer.Â  Id.; see also Murrells
    Inlet Corp., 378 S.C. at 233, 662 S.E.2d at 455-56; McAllister v. Smiley,
  301 S.C. 10, 12, 389 S.E.2d 857, 859 (1990).[3]Â  
Here,
  Respondent prepared a plat describing the way he intended to subdivide his
  property into three lots, two of which were to go to his children.Â  He ultimately
  conveyed ownership of only one lot and now claims an easement by dedication
  across it.Â  However, because an easement by dedication benefits the buyer, this
  presumption is unavailable to Respondent, the seller.Â  Consequently, Respondent
  does not possess an easement by dedication across Appellantâ€™s land.Â  
II.  Other
  Issues
Appellant
  additionally asserts the master erred in violating her due process rights and
  in failing to rule on her motions for summary judgment.Â  Due to our disposition
  of Appellantâ€™s first issue, we need not address the remaining issues on appeal. See Futch v. McAllister Towing of Georgetown, Inc., 335 S.C. 598,
  613, 518 S.E.2d 591, 598 (1999) (ruling an appellate court need not review remaining issues when its determination of a
  prior issue is dispositive of the appeal). 
CONCLUSION
As
  to the issue of Respondentâ€™s easement, we find Respondent does not have an
  easement by dedication across Appellantâ€™s land.Â  Therefore, we reverse the masterâ€™s
  order on this issue.Â  
Accordingly,
  the masterâ€™s order is 
REVERSED.
HEARN, C.J., KONDUROS, J., and GOOLSBY, A.J., concur.Â  


[1] We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to
  Rule 215, SCACR.
[2] The western end of Respondentâ€™s property does not
  appear on the Inman Plat.Â  
[3] Our supreme court explored the policies underlying implied
  public and private easements by dedication in Cason v. Gibson, 217 S.C.
  500, 61 S.E.2d 58 (1950).Â

PER CURIAM: In
  this post-conviction relief (PCR) case, we granted certiorari to review the PCR
  judge's grant of relief for Roy Edward Hook.Â  We reverse. [1] 
Hook
  applied for PCR after his five-year probationary sentence was revoked in full.Â 
  After a hearing, the PCR judge granted relief, finding Hook's counsel was
  ineffective for (1) failing to call witnesses on Hook's behalf and (2) failing
  to object when a probation agent informed the revocation judge of Hook's
  pending criminal charges.Â  We find neither ground supports a finding of
  ineffective assistance of counsel.Â  
1.Â 
  At the PCR hearing, Hook did not proffer the testimony of the witnesses he
  argues counsel should have called during the probation revocation hearing.Â 
  Accordingly, he had failed to show how he was prejudiced by any deficient
  performance of his revocation counsel.Â  See Porter v. State, 368 S.C.
  378, 386, 629 S.E.2d 353, 358 (2006) ("Mere speculation of what a witness'[s]
  testimony may be is insufficient to satisfy the burden of showing prejudice in
  a petition for PCR."); Dempsey v. State, 363 S.C. 365, 369, 610
  S.E.2d 812, 814 (2005) (holding a PCR applicant cannot show that he was
  prejudiced by counsel's failure to call a favorable witness to testify at trial
  if that witness does not later testify at the PCR hearing or otherwise offer
  testimony within the rules of evidence); Strickland v. Washington, 466
  U.S. 668, 687 (1984) (explaining in order to establish a claim of ineffective
  assistance of counsel, a PCR applicant must prove: (1) counsel's performance
  was deficient, and (2) the deficient performance prejudiced the applicant's
  case).Â  
2.Â 
  When the revocation judge revoked Hook's probation in full, he cited the
  following grounds: (1) failure to report; (2) conviction for writing fraudulent
  checks; and (3) failure to follow his probation agent's advice.Â  Because the
  charges pending against Hook were not the reason for revoking his probation,
  Hook again failed to prove the prejudice prong of Strickland v. Washington.
  466 U.S. at 687.
REVERSED.
HEARN, C.J., CURETON, A.J., and GOOLSBY, A.J.

  Rule 215, SCACR.
